reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have finished the game and found 2 secrets (I think), so it is time for me to write an alpha review of this game.

As many people here said this before me: THE ATMOSPHERE IS AWESOME!
The style of this game fits it perfectly and some decisions you must make are really great and add a lot to the atmosphere (I would like more of these :)
Also I am Slavic by myself Czech to be exact (This game is made by Poland developers, we are neighbours) so the story and settings that this game has is more familiar with me, interesting and creepier and I enjoy it much more than lets say: Amnesia (don´t eat me alive, just my opinion).
The notes and old photos, old things that people left there, that you can find are very interesting and they will drive you more into the situation of the game.
Locations are also very interesting (and dangerous) and I always felt good (I am the adventurous type, I explored few deserted locations in real life, I enjoy these things a lot) and also weirded/creeped out when I was exploring some new building or landmark.
Just look on the web for pictures preferably (it is for your own good), but be careful this game can be easilly spoilered (or can I just say spoiled? Not a native speaker here, sorry!), so don´t look on gameplays much, if you want to buy it.

The camera from the birds point of view is also very nicely done, like for example when you are stranded in the forest, you can see the branches of the trees and fallen trees and the effects like: lights and shadows in buildings are very nice. There is also physics, that adds interesting mechanics like: pushing various objects to barricade yourself from an enemy that is chasing you,
or pushing against doors when something tries to walk in.
Also you can barricade with planks and nails of course, when you have the time.
Or if you throw something it will slide on the ground, so you can see the physics in action.
You can also run into the doors to break them open, when you are running from an enemy.

It has of course a good amount of bugs or glitches, like light problem when some parts of the forest will flicker for a second so you can´t see, and also dissapearing enemies, that occured to me quite often with chompers.
To explain you the glitch/bug: Sometimes when it was chasing me it would dissapear and stopped attacking until I bumb into it accidentally or look in other direction for it, then it would quickly appear and almost kill you or start chasing you)
Also I would change the fighting system a bit (it is really hard to hit something with the axe and or shovel, because it just takes too long to ''charge'' the attack) and breaking of the melee weapons (they break unnecesearly/unrealistically often) and the crafting system is very small and simple, maybe add more variety and complexity, like new barricading structures and weapons.

The developers are quite active and responsive also the updates are every month (more or less).
So everything will get better and the game will get bigger after some time.
The developers will have to do their best as the game is far from completion.

Also this game is rather hard and will not hold your hand.
There is a prologue, that will teach you few things, but then you are on your own and you will have to act like you would act in that situation, you must adapt to it.

If you are searching for some new horror-survival game and if you are a fan of deep atmosphere and story games, that is not only about the blood/gore and jumpscares GO FOR THIS ONE, you won´t regret it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Darkwood is a top-down-perspective survival thriller(?). The epilogue (which is absolutely brilliant) gives you some basic hints as to how combine items, interact with the environment, swing an axe and that is basically it. Then you wake up in a shabby old house with one wall missing, meet a mysterious wolf-man and head out to explore.

And you die.

Then you wake up again, make a mental note not to ♥♥♥♥ off any dogs, and set out again.

Then you die once more – another note made – and you already know it’s going to be one hell of a ride.
Thing is, the game is rather difficult and at times can be truly challenging and unforgiving. However, If you die, you die because you made (a) mistake(s), because you were unprepared or just because you lacked experience (and I don’t mean leveling your character). It takes time to get the hang of it and actually start surviving for a change, but then again this learning process is damn rewarding  – no one is holding your hand, nobody tells you where to go and what to do. Thus, every little accomplishment feels good. Really good.

Darkwood is all about exploration, survival and atmosphere. The world is a twisted, dream-like place (partially randomized) where you’re bound to get lost. There is a map,  yes, but your current location is not marked on it. You have to pay attention to landmarks, remember where you’re going and where you came from. Otherwise you won’t be able to make it home before nighttime. And, believe me, you don’t want to be out when the night comes. You want to barricade yourself at the (not-at-all) safe-house, set some traps, hide in a corner and hope to gods the monsters leave you be. And perhaps cry a little as you hear scratching, howling, barking and what not coming from the other side of the wall. If the monsters do get in and you find yourself poorly equipped, you’re dead. You feel surrounded and helpless, and yet ready to try your hardest to make your stand until morning when all the horrors disappear like a bad dream. Sometimes the nights can be soothingly calm, but you’ll keep sitting in that corner of yours all tense, anticipating the worst. Sometimes a banshee just walks around your hideout, opens doors and move pieces of furniture around, not doing much harm (unless you attack) and still scaring the living crap out of you. You never know what to expect and it makes the whole experience even better.

If you happen to survive the night, you’ll wander off again to replenish resources (which are scarce and don’t respawn), eventually venturing into darker, more dangerous parts of the forest. There are guns (some are difficult to find though) but don’t get trigger-happy as ammo is hard to obtain and expensive. You’ll be forced to go melee most of the time. And, don’t get me wrong, you’ll probably try to avoid fighting all together anyway. This is NOT a beat’em up kind of game. Dying is easy.

It is also NOT a horror game as such. The mood is heavy but don’t expect cheap jump scares. There might be some, as your cone of vision (another sweet idea) allows you to see only a bit of what’s in front of you and leaves you exposed to all sorts of dangers lurking in the darkness, but it is not scripted. If you get jump-scared, it’s because you were not careful enough. Most of the times.

The game in its current version (1.3) offers only the prologue and the first chapter but it is a fairly long trip and holds great replayability value. Also, it might be the most polished and bug-free alpha game I have ever played and I have played quite a few. Give it a try and see for yourself.

DAY 1
woke up and ran around, no idea what to do
found a small shack and went inside.

Quickly scramble into my corner and wait until day

Run away and get pelted in the head again

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Darkwood was released recently for early access as an early alpha build. However, I was impressed by how not-early-access it felt. Many games these days are released as early access, people pay money, and they get a messy incomplete game. Like The Fifth Day for example. Darkwood is not like these games that just seem like a cash-grab for developers. The game thus far is very well made. I don’t recall encountering a single bug, there’s actually story, and there are things to do! I was really impressed by how well the developers, Acid Wizard, captured a creepy, eerie, dark essence to the game. It really immerses you into this freaky, weird place. The game is also very challenging, it is not a brainless walk in the park by any means. In fact, I struggled to even get much of anywhere into the questing and story in the six hours I played. I am not sure why but I could not find the violin boy’s parents house at all. The “not far” part of the message is misleading because I searched everywhere the entire time I played (two different games) and never could find it. Perhaps it is just the luck of the randomly generated world, a feature I think makes this game fun and adds a lot of replay value.

Overall, the game in its current state is solid and worth the $15 price tag. If you’re a fan of darker survival games, I recommend giving Darkwood a try.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wow what a game!
I hardly every do reviews but this is special

Despite my short amount of game time (I'll be going back on as soon as I've recommended this) I have enjoyed it a huge amount so far... So here it is:

Graphics: 8.5/10 - Oh boy the graphics! By far the best rogue-like graphics I have ever seen. the dark, creepy and grainy effects really put you on edge... Not to mention how void of colour it is (Not a bad thing as it helps the tension and atmosphere) and oh god the lighting is amazing...

Gameplay: 8/10 - the crafting is very straightforward, but efficient, the combat is very tough. I struggled on my first enemy! (MLG) But it works. It also really reminded me of RE4 (Resident Evil 4) which is one of my fav survival horrors out there.

Soundtrack 9/10 - Wow. That's the only way to describe the amazing soundtrack. Just, Just WOW.

Bugs 9/10 - I've only spotted a couple bugs so far.. text out of place,etc.

Optimization - 8/10 - Man it's good. I can run this full settings with my crappy little notebook. Although has it's choppy moments, will be improved!

Overall rating - 8.5/10 This game so far is great, the prologue was fantastic, the gameplay is good and the story seems interesting too. A great pickup and I strongly recommend you buying it! (Review will be updated).

Bye babes x

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Development for this game may be slow, but this is a case where quality comes before quantity.

Darkwood is an amazing experience. It's creepy and atmospheric, full of genuine mysteries that make you wonder WTF is really going on in this twisted, decaying world.

The gameplay experience isn't terrifying and stressful (like in Amnesia) but it's definitely tense and exciting. It forces you to respect the dangers of the world and plan you actions. Combat is risky. Building and fortifying a secure hideout is crucial to survival. Wandering outside at night is suicide.

I played version Alpha 4.2 and enjoyed every second of it. It's not a complete game yet but it's a more satisfying game experience than some triple-A titles out there. Totally recommended to anyone seeking an immersive survival horror RPG experience.

Such a romanticly erotic masterpiece, kidding. This game takes an underrated perspective, and makes it work well again. Most games that have been released with such an art direction as well as perspective have been highly lack luster. this game marries the concept of ambience(via lighting, audio and environment generation) with the idea of having a false sense of awareness in the space that you currently occupy to create a sense of fear that has been hard to find since the original resident evil games. notably, this game is a true Survival Horror game with a psychologically engaging story told in the most spectacular way. The story is told in a very david lynch~ish style, similar to hotline miami.... but lets not make that mistake and get the two mixed up as they are both two extremely different game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Type of Game:

Top-down horror survival PDL with crafting elements

Version Played:

Early Access PC version through Steam

Similar Games:

Teleglitch, Don’t Starve, the Silent Hill series, and to a lesser degree Hotline Miami

The Good:

A truly intriguing storyline filled with mysteries around every corner. It feels like you’ve stepped into a Silent Hill storyline, but crafted by David Lynch.
This makes exploration a much more enjoyable experience as uncovering parts of the story really add depth to the game
The game is really difficult, which adds A LOT to the tension of each decision you make. The lack of resources and constant sense of dread creates an experience similar to playing Dark Souls, except just way scarier (quite a feat, I know).
Randomly generated maps help with the sense of disorientation each time you play and adds to the replayability of the title.
The crafting aspect to the game is very deep and intuitive. As I mentioned before, resources are limited, so finding a stockpile of items is a very rewarding experience.
Crafting also lends itself to the defense building that needs to occur every game night, which if you find yourself itemless during well… just make sure you have plenty of wood and nails.
The music and ambient noise is appropriately creepy and adds to the horror of playing.
Combat is easy to grasp and works very similarly to Hotline Miami, which can lead to some frantic combat scenarios.
The intentional lack of hand-holding in the beginning of the game can create a constant sense of discovery not unlike Don’t Starve.

The Bad:

As expected for an early access title, the game has bugs and glitches which can ruin the immersion at times. Though definitely not as bad as other early access titles.
One example of a bug was a loading problem, which caused some difficulty picking up where I left off when trying to access a saved game. This has since been addressed.
Another bug (as the dev team has referred to it as such in the forums) is the excruciatingly long initial world generation time. I had thought that the game had crashed the first time I played, though stuck around luckily due to the music still playing. This is something they are working on.
Currently only Chapter One is available, which is bad only because I want more of this amazing game!

Can you play it while the children are awake?

No… Just no.

Did I make time to complete it?

I finished what was currently available, which was Chapter One.

Redlight or Greenlight?

This game is currently at a greenlight.

The content that is currently offered is well worth the asking price of $14.99. The experience is a horror game fan’s terrifying bliss. Darkwood has mysteries around every corner, frightening sounds you feel like you imagined, fearsome creatures that don’t relent, frenzied combat that leaves you breathless, and panicked defense building which all come together to create a phenomenal gaming experience. Knowing there is more to come is just icing on the cake.

A Quick Look at Those Games You Might Buy:
www.gamersglance.com

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 1
I hate this place. It appears I am trapped in a cottage, if I try to venture beyond the thick congealment of mist, I see stirring shapes and shadows, none look too friendly. The only things here are some nails and boards, and that rusty old bear trap on the wall...

Day 2
It started last night, the thirst. It's hard to explain, it's like an uncontrollable urge. As long as I have this strange well I should be fine. I have barricaded most of the house, and put a bear trap near the gaping hole in the wall.

Day 3
It appears the local fauna have chosen to stray closer to my cottage. Unfortunate. I will have to keep an extra eye out. Also, I swear I can hear some sort of sinister sound over the mire.

Day 4
It's getting louder. A small man, perhaps a child is playing a horrible and tune on what used to be a violin.

Day 8
I can't take it anymore, the mortifying curls of the violin pierce my brain with every note, it's driving me mad. My only sanity comes from the soft patter of the rain and the hallucinogenic mushrooms I cooked and injected myself with while trying to put myself out of my misery.

Day 14
...

Day 20
They're mocking me. All of them, I can't trust anyone. Not the damned violinist, or the sweet old chicken lady.  Heh, her face wouldn't be so sweet if it adorned my wall...

Day Unknown
I'm stuck in the last room of the cottage. Everything else was ether burned or absorbed by it. The spirits whisper at my door, telling my to come out and die. The offer is begining to sound tempting. You know, the songs aren't so bad now. How does it go? Little Skylark Little Skylark

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Gibbering Writhing black-mouthed chaos. Wretched foul monstrousities. The guttural wails of the half-dead and the better-off-dead. Savages made from the displacement of humanity. Beastial dogs and creatures that can only be found through the utter putrification of nature. This is what Darkwood offers. It offers something, wholly unique. It offers a world of terror and fright that some people would pass off because of it being a 2D topdown survival horror game. And as a person who has been playing it as long as I have (I think the week it came out) I remember all the phases.
I remember the wells at night and the mad scrambles you would make to get home. I remember scavenging through the woods and the zones trying to forage the necessary equipment to keep yourself alive. I see now, that the game has only gotten better. I remember being lucky enough to find the mirror and knowing I am nothing worse than the ghosts that surround me.
When I heard it received a series of updats, I was so delighted to return to the same grim, familiar surroundings. Wolf, Chicken Lady, the poor violin kid and all the the other horrors lying in wait, with baited breath and hungry teeth, all these things made me want to come back with utter determination.
I got his violin, I dragged myself a chair, I brought the Lynx back through the whole forest murdering everything in my path and contemplated murder so many times on Wolf's behalf. I met new people with nothing to say, like The Three, and fought new enemies, like the horrfiying Elk.
I traversed the corn maze and I went through, carefully picking and choosing my battles until I made my way back into the same, awful woods I slithered from where I lived in the lap of squallid luxury.
This is a game, where nobody is good, they are merely doing things for the sake of themselves. You can feel pity, but there is evil in everything.
The cost of fresh pork? Experience a beast you can only slay by talking to a Rocket Man.
That violin? You will learn what you must face to redeem the price of a sad child..
That prized sow that belongs to the chicken lady? You will see the price of fresh milk in a place where nothing grows.
The efforts of the Black Box? A careful eye will reveal its secret.
A Red Swing. A Black Box. A White Dress.
All the secrets of an apocalyptic bastion of woodland can offer you. The game is unfinished. But it's definitely worth your time. I buy and play a lot of survival games, and with the modern few I love like Frozen State, Sheltered and a few others, I offer this game a very special place in my heart.
I can't review it, but if my views on the game here are any insight, buy it. Buy it cheap if you're thrifty, but buy it all the same. To me, this was like... Playing Darkwood is like planning surgery. You prepare yourself in lackluster scrubs, you enter the operating area half dazed by all the blood, and you hope to christ you don't die in the process of accomplishing your task-at-hand. It's the effort made whether you live to the end of the day, or die in a single run.
Getting a gun is nice, but it doesn't kill everything in a single blast. Getting fully upgraded melee weapons is an accomplishment in and of itself but using them and surviving is what feels good.
Taking on your first fight with a Chomper and winning? That's what makes the game all the worthwhile.
Sure there are bugs, but I haven't a doubt in my mind they'll get fixed. Just as more mystery is made, more problems must be solved. And with any amount of effort made, I can only stand by the game being utterly, and totally satisfied for the low, low price of 15 dollars.
The many ugly and unwholesome secrets of Darkwood lay ahead, awaiting your arrival. Why don't you sit and stay a spell? Don't forget your nailboard and bandages, because it's going to be a rough ride into madness friend.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let's just get one thing straight.
Darkwood is a brutal game. A REALLY brutal game.
If you love challanges, this game is definitely for you.

If you're into zombie/scavanger type survival games this is definitely a must have then.

Let's start off with with this game is

Darkwood is a horror game that only goes well if you plan ahead of time.

After the prologue tutorial, you play as a man with very little amounts of resources to start off with. You run around in the day time looking for wood, nails, just about anything you can fit into your invetory screen as almost all of it is important. Eventually, you'll notice that you have to go back to your hide out before night fall to drink from a well and hole up in your home. This is where it get's really interesting, and where most of your strategic planning comes into play.

During the night, you'll be forced to drink from a well just outside your house, which enables you to live through the night. If you don't drink from the well in-time though, you'll start losing health untill you do. So don't travel to far out without a watch (Which you must find, or buy. You don't start off with one), or a decent sense of how long it takes to reach night time. After you drink from the well, you're most likely going to run back into your home. You can close the doors, block the hole up in your house with your furniture, and barricade the doors and windows with either panks of wood, or just more furniture. Next, you can lay traps that you may have found on your journey, arm yourself with any weapons you have crafted or found, and after alllll of that, you're going to sit, and wait for morning. And wait... and wait... oh god what are those foot steps I'm hearing? What is that growling sound? Jeezes what's with all the crows? Oh ♥♥♥♥ something is inside the house

With that being said, the game has a stealth mechanic to it. Monsters have to know where you are in order to attack you. Sure they spawn outside the house at night, but they don't know your exact location yet. First off, monsters listen for your foot steps. Step to close to one that's just on the other side of the wall, and he's going to know where you are.    break into your house, and start looking for you. You can hide behind furniture, or lock yourself in another room though, maybe set up a trap at the door way.

Oh, I forgot to mention, during the night, assuming you've already found out how mushrooms and leveling up work, you're going to occasionally be attacked by shadows. It won't happen every night, just every now and then. Every hide out has a generator that produces electricity for your lamps. You need gasoline (fuel) to make it work though, so don't forget to turn those things on before you go into hiding. Any source of will keep the shadows from hurting you during the night, be it flares, flashlight (Though that requires some aiming) or just lighting a fire with some gasoline.

After every night, during the morning of the next day, you're going to be visited by The three." These guys are going to end up being your main source of resources later on down the road.  And time for the game will freeze for the morning

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the most innovative horror titles I've ever played.

Spooky forest simulator by day, home invasion simulator by night.
This game runs with so many common human fears that it leaves its unfortunate players babbling incoherently in a corner and jumping at shadows hours after exiting.
Or maybe that's just me...

Don't let the simplistic top down view fool you, you can forget the world is represented in 2D with the extremely immersive atmosphere and incredible sound design. All this coupled with challenging but rewarding gameplay and an intruiging developing story makes this game a MUST-HAVE for horror gaming fans.

Add this to your library and share its existance with all of your internet buddies, because this game is a rare indie developer gem.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Below you'll find both a written and a video impressions on the game
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FVBrrpN8raM
As an early access Darkwood is fairly solid. I didn't find any bugs or glitches, and the game never crashed. It does suffer from some optimization issues, mainly the long load time. As for the game it self, it's pretty enjoyable, if not, at least a unique experience.

Darkwood takes the survival horror genre and put it into a top down perspective, with an excellent aesthetic style. Visually the game is of a high caliber. The background and foreground elements are detailed and stylized, while still maintaining visual clarity so the player can easily decipher what items are interactable. The game's sound design is equally admirable. Your footsteps sound realistic and heavy, with the ground it treads on matching the steps you take. You'll hear random twig snaps, and kicks of pebbles. Crows in the distance, and animals in the shrubs, with a light but moody sound track to kick in the appropriate moments, and you have a game that's a real treat for the ears, as well as the eyes. The game's sinister atmosphere is further echoed by the use of light, both for visual interest as well as using light as a mechanics on it's own.

The game also features an interesting chapter by chapter story structure as well, with the current build being the prologue. With out giving too much away, let's say at the game's first turning point, a fairly major and unexpected reviel will instantly grab your curiosity.

Though the game is quite enjoyable even at this early stage, it's not with out it's faults. On the technical side. long load times can drive a person's patience, and the game's lack of features and options is also worth noting. Mechanically speaking once you start playing with the more sandboxy elements of the game, you could find yourself in long stretches wandering seemingly aimlessly, wondering where your next objective is, or if you're even going the right" way. To be fair
date: this isn't so much a problem with Darkwood it self
hoursPlayed: a common issue with survival games in general.\n\nOverall the game is a quality product already
voteText:
and I can only see it getting better with time. I believe I can safely recommend Darkwood if you are interested in the idea of a top-down sandbox-ish survival horror.

Pros:
- Great graphics
- Interesting plot
- A new take on survival horror
- Great sound design
- Good lighting

Cons:
- Long load times
- Can get boring when searching for next objective
- Limited features and options"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game.
It's something I've never played before: top down+horror=unique gameplay.
Nights are scary. Not only must you hide from savages lurking around your hideout, but the shadows that want to consume you. Grab a torch and pray for the night to end!
There are three sections in the map: Meadows, The Forest and The Old Woods. Each of these zones are harder than the other, and the farther you go, the more interesting locations you can find.
After strolls around the woods harvesting odd mushrooms and meat, you can return to your hideout and cook it into a liquid substance and inject yourself with a dose. This lets you choose one skill from the first tier, however, each tier has its negative skills aswell, such as the shadows, mentioned before.
You'll find yourself dying alot, the map may be hard to use as it doesnt show where you exactly are unless near a certain location, but worry not, it shows where you died and lost your inventory, so you can try to retrieve your precious loot.

I definitely recommend this game to people who want some hardcore horror survival!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI was an original back of the game back in April of 2013, I wanted a true survival horror and Acid Wizard seemed to know what makes a game truly scary and tense. Note that I have only played the game for about an hour, this was so that I don't get bored of the game before it is released like I did with StarBound, so take this review with a grain of salt. The game so far is what I would call a true survival horror experience, the atmosphere is dark and oppressive with ambient sound that constantly keep you on edge and constantly checking your back, thinking something is going to constantly going to murder your horribly. I have seen one or two jump scares, mostly something behind me I didn't notice. These, however, weren’t bad jump scares, they happened during times when I was fully immersed in the game and I was already scared. One of the problems I had are that some of the controls are a little clunky. To swing a melee weapon, you hold down left click to raise the weapon, then right click to swing instead of letting go of left mouse. This feels intentional, like how Silent Hill 1-3 had awful combat to hamper the player, but it is still awkward, not too awkward and you get used to it, but it may cause a few deaths. The game is buggy at sometimes as well, I once was stuck looking in a box because a menu failed to pop up. I was stuck until a cosmic monstrosity decided that I was looking tasty, which did scare me, but it does need to be fixed along with others that may show up. From my experience, I'd recommend the game, but I'd wait until the full game is released, unless you like taking part in Early Access games or you wish to support the developers. I'd like to see how the game improves over the Early Access time to the final release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is gonna be a long one so I'm gonna summarize here. If you're looking for a perfect blend of sandbox and horror then this game will definitely tickle your fancy. I highly recommend it even if it is early access. Normally I hate early access. People throwing out unfinished games to the masses. This is the one exception. Don't hesitate in getting this now if you're interested. It's damn good and feels like a finished game.

Day oneFirst day of the game I was terrified. I had no idea when night was coming. My inventory was full and I quickly realized my map doesn't show my exact position. I had to figure it out on my own using landmarks I've located. This was my first major mistake. I was lost. I could see the sun was beginning to set and I was still lost deep within the woods. I was so cocky. When I first booted the game I turned on permadeath thinking I could ace this game like any other horror or sandbox game I've played. None of them set the atmosphere quite like Darkwood did. Nothing frightened me more than seeing the sun come down. I began panicking, sprinting my way through the forest hoping for any sort of shelter. Of course I didn't find any. I did find the road however and with it, eventually my home. It was pitch dark outside and I made the huge mistake of leaving the generator on. I was so stupid. I assumed the gas I put in it would last longer or it'd just stop using fuel during the day. The typical gaming conventions I was used to wasn't present in this game. Not even the sight of my own home made me feel any relief. I'd made another horrible mistake. I hadn't had time to barricade the windows during the day. I shut myself in one of the rooms and pushed all manner of furniture in front of the doors and windows, hoping it'd keep whatever was out there away. I had no idea what I was up against. But I could hear them. I had run out of furniture to push against any openings. There was one window I had to keep open and for the rest of the night I stared at it from across the room. I spent the whole night, weapon raised, staring out that window terrified for my life.

ReviewI've watched this game in development for a while and I was pleasantly surprised to see a developer actually deliver an amazing game for early access. I had my doubts. I really wanted to get this game when it was finished so I could get the whole experience but I couldn't resist any longer. Boy was I impressed though. It felt like a complete game. Of course I bought it shortly after most of the bugs had been squashed so I didn't really get to see how buggy it may have been early on. They've already thrown out so many bug fixes in the short amount of time it's been released that I definitely have high hopes for its development.
A lot of survival horror" game developers just don't get what makes a horror game truly terrifying. I've seen countless of these horror games that rely solely on jump scares or just putting the character in a dark room with a flashlight. And what few games have that right kind of atmosphere have ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game-play. Darkwood does this flawlessly. Not only is it in a terrifying setting
date: but it's also fun to play. The most important thing to any horror media (be it a movie
recommended: book or game) is setting the tone. You need the player to feel immersed in this atmosphere or they won't give a damn about the character's well-being. I was genuinely scared I wouldn't be able to make it home the first night. I had absolutely no idea what I was up against and I didn't want to know. All I knew is that it wanted me dead. I wasn't even sure if the dressers I pressed against the doors and windows would even protect me from them. Its that mystery that makes the game so effective at being scary. Not once did I feel like I was truly safe. Even as the sun came up.\nAll in all this was definitely one of the scariest experiences I've had with a game. I highly recommend it to anyone with a taste for horror. Darkwood will forever be my measuring stick for judging what a true survival horror game should be.\n"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

1st day.

Been saved by a strange wolf man.
He has answers. Been told to find a chicken lady.
She will tell me about my attacker.
Went out looking for mushrooms to make a brew.
Got dark. Went back home and blocked a hole in the wall.

2nd day.

Went exploring. Found a man whom refuses to leave his room, in a over grown house.
Said he will not leave his room untill whatever was in his shed was gone.
I avoided the shed due to lack of a weapon. Got dark, headed back. Heard a dog yelp
during the night.

3rd day.

Found blood outside my house. Nothing else.
Found a farm while following a path. Entered a house next to the farm.
Strang man was yelling at me. Left him alone, but took the axe on the floor.
Investigated the farm. found a locked door. Broke it down with the axe.
Dead pigs littered the floor, but my curiosity drove me onward.
More blood, and dead pigs, with a few live ones running around.
At the very end of the blood and gore was something.
I have no idea what it was. I threw some matches at it to see what it was.
It moved violently, and my courage failed. I ran out of that place and made a
bee line for my home.
repaired a door way and boardered up all windows apart from one due
to lack of resources.....

Night fell, and I ran out to drink from the well.... I did not see the massive hound untill it bit me.
I panic and swing rapidly, not caring how strong my swings were, just wanting it to die, or leave me. I killed it.
But I'm not doing so well. The dog badly wounded me, and
I have turned all lights off, to stop anything getting attracted to my home. I'm too scared to do anything about
the corpse. I know it will attract something, but I don't have the courage to go back out there. So I sit with my back
against the cabint I placed to block the hole in the wall.

Heard a creek. I thought, it was the trees. No, I prayed it was the trees. Heard another creek. Must be the wind.
But I still watch the door infront of me. I watched it closer when I saw it swing open. Something walked into the room.
It did not seem to see me. It turned to explore the rest of my home. I panic and swing my axe into its back. It screams
a vile screech and dies. My heart racing, I slam the door shut.

The danger was not over. To my horror I heard the door, creak from a swing. Something was breaking into the room. I fled to the last room and slam the door closed. Listening, I heard the beast scan the room for me. Then proceed to attack I was holding down. The door was about to fall apart untill it stopped. I thought morning must of broke, but the sunlight did not fill the room. It was still pitch black. I wondered why the attacks stopped untill my brain registered the fact I left one window unbarricaded. That window was the window in the room I was hiding in. I was half way swinging the door open when the things teeth slammed into my waist and tore me in half.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

God this game is dripping in evil.
Buy it. 8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

/After a few hours with the first alpha release

I'm so happy I backed this game, if they can keep generating more content like what's already in the game I'll be more than satisfied.

The game seems semi-structured with story elements introduced via fetch quests and interaction with the other characters present in the game world. Some random generation to the environments promotes replaying but seeing as i've only been playing a few hours I can't comment on how much it affects each playthrough. The audio and visuals work really well together to create an oppressively creepy atmosphere and playing with headphones is a must for the full effect.

Darkwood is the type of game that will make celebrity youtubers ♥♥♥♥ their pants for their audiences entertainment, and whilst there are plenty of jump scares it's the art and sound design that really chills the bones along with a limited view of your surroundings the feeling of never being safe is always present.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has great atmosphere and an interesting setting and story that you discover as you explore. If you like survival exploration games with a touch of the weird, then this is definitely worth checking out.

An important caveat: although there are are currently some random elements in the game, this is primarily limited to the location of the major....err....locations of the game. That is to say sometimes a particular house will be north of your starting area, and sometimes it'll be south, or east. But the locations themselves are always the same once you get to them.

Although there's a way to save your progress, new game versions tend to wipe your saves so you end up having to start over. Enough restarts and you'll may get tired of going over the same section of the game over and over.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game went into early access in July 2014. I can't say I know what it was like back then but from what I've seen as of patch 3.1-4.0 I was very impressed!

For a top down game it is very atmospheric and scary. Gameplay consists of searching for resources during the day and defending your hideout at night. If you somehow manage to find the time then also progressing the plot.

Resources don't respawn and you need them to survive the nights so you will inevitably be forced to advance deeper into the forest to a new hideout and continously search for a way to escape the forest before you are overwhelmed or run out of resources.

In patch 3.1 it was easy to survive by pulling a wardrobe into a corner with you boxed in to be safe. However as of patch 4.1 poltergeists throw around the furniture if you do this and the noise attracts more monsters. Players can survive by barricading windows and doors, setting traps, lighting the house with a gas generator, igniting enemies with strategically placed gasoline and a lit match, and fighting with a variety of melee weapons and if you are lucky maybe a gun

The game has optional permadeath and the enemies are extremely dangerous. You never feels safe and every day feels like a mad rush for resources. However for me this was a negative as the constant day to day rushing made me feel like I don't have time to soak the atmosphere or proceed with caution. Days are slightly longer in 4.1 however... I would like to see a system where time passes as the player advances from one location to another and once the player reaches a location like, say, the burned houses then time becomes normal until the player leaves, giving the player time to explore carefully

It is in mid alpha right now, and I feel they should have progressed to beta by now but not that it is way too slow either. The devs are very communicative and take criticism into account very well. They tend to reply to post in most topics and never get mad even at people who are trolling

I'd say this is one of the games worth paying to get at early access, but I don't want to encourage early access so for those who like games like dark souls, survival games and roguelikes definetly get it when it is released :D
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While I would recommend this game for fans of atmospheric roguelikes and horror mysteries, I have to do so with a few big caveats. The top-down dark view the game uses makes it extremely difficult to tell what you're looking at to the point where half your time is spent bumping up against big gloomy objects. The day/night cycle isn't clearly defined so you never know when night is coming and you need to get back to your base, though I'm not sure it matters since there doesn't appear to be any penalty to dying so you might as well use it as a sort of quick-travel to get home. Combat is pretty clunky to the point where it feels awkward and punishing in a way that has nothing to do with difficulty.

That said, the atmosphere and mood are absolutely stellar, especially in the opening prologue of the game, and the character artwork is amazing. It's clear that there's been a lot of thought towards making this a tense and difficult survival simulation with a real story to it, and it's a story that's a genuinely intriguing one too. The concept of exploring, hunting, scavenging, and barricading is solid, but at the moment my concern is that it seems like the biggest emphasis has been on style instead of polishing the gameplay mechanics. Yeah, I know, it's Early Access. I funded this last year. But playing a game, even a game that's intended to be a difficult one, shouldn't feel like an uphill battle where the game is fighting you instead of challenging you. With tweaks to its UI to provide more helpful feedback and a less obtuse combat system, Darkwood has a lot of potential, and I hope it lives up to it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game currently is excellent in what it tries to do. In regards to other games within its category, there is still a lot to be desired. There really isn't this sense of an active world, but, rather, set pieces that are very nicely done. Characters are interesting and I enjoy the look of em, but they never really do anything within the world. Combat feels nice. Atmosphere is excellent. I do have issues with the mandatory well mechanic in which you must drink from your specific well to not die. This prevents really any long term exploration or, what i would call, travelling and living as a nomad. It also seems rather arbitrary as no one else appears to have to undergo this same process despite also having wells <all broken>. There is also the issue of having nothing to do when waiting throughout the night. My experiences have either been immense boredom <which happens when the night noises become routine> or small moments of stress at later nights. But, for the nights, there is never this sense of productivity, just waiting.

As it stands, for what it wants to be, it is excellent. Would I play it over games like Pathologic? No.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My review to Darkwood

So what makes Darkwood different from other games that strive to unsettle you? Well, for starters, Darkwood doesn’t hinge on jump-inducing surprise-scares for its sense of tension (though it promises its fair share of these moments, anyways). Instead, Darkwood places you in a procedurally generated forest in a deeply twisted perversion of Soviet Russia. From there, the game’s dismal lighting, grotesque ambiance, and overall eerie atmosphere create the horror themselves.

darkwood horror survival game gameplayIn other words, Darkwood doesn’t rely on cheap scare tactics and bursts of adrenaline to generate its terror. Darkwood’s brand of fear is the type that starts as a knot of unease in your stomach, a knot that grows tighter with each door you push slowly open, with every backwards glance and each spectral groan that floats out of the fog. Darkwood doesn’t try to scare you in the traditional Western sense – it tricks you into scaring yourself.

Of course, we can’t talk about innovation in the genre without looking into the very thing that made the game stand out to me in the first place – its choice of perspective. Where most horror games seek to attach you to the protagonist by making you look through their eyes, Darkwood is the embodiment of detachment. You look down on your character from above, your line of sight limited to the swath of your flashlight beam.

This means that behind you, inside buildings, anywhere that your light can’t reach, is blanketed in darkness. Nightmarish things lurk outside the light, things that you will be forced to encounter as you drift through the corrupted forest. Whether or not you survive these brushes with the frightful unknown is entirely up to you.

What Else?

In addition to the top-down view, Darkwood introduces some more interesting ideas. Its design has been inspired by rogue-like, adventure, and role-playing games alike, giving it a unique and nuanced feel that it seems only indie games can achieve these days.

Its diverse inspirations give Darkwood a well-rounded approach to the genre, providing something enticing for every flavor of gamer. Its RPG roots have inspired the developers to include a skill-tree to the game, allowing character diversification and specialization. The looting and crafting systems are reminiscent of many survival games, from Minecraft to Fortnite, but are presented in their own uniquely gritty ways.

My Rating

8/10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nTo give you an idea of what this games like it took me three tries to survive the first night. Finally I was able to scrounge up enough wood and nails to baricade a door and window and fashion a makeshift nailboard. I spent the night huddled up in the dark listening to the sounds from outside, jumping at small movements. Just when I thought I would make it there was a terrific crash as something began to batter down my baracades. I had no choice but to stand there, board raised waiting as the barricades duribility ticked down. But at about a quarter strength something happened there was a new growling from outside and what sounded like an attack. The beating on my barricade stopped and when morning came and I went outside there was just a few bloodstains outside the window. Terrifying sound design.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Few games have been able to invite the sheer terror that this happens to provoke. The sound design is fantastic, and it helps to convey a sense of impending doom during the night sequences, when you're hunkered down in your choice of shelter. You can hear the beasts skulking around in the rooms around you, banging on barricades, stepping on creaking floorboards, and howling into the dead of night, while you remain huddled in a corner, wishing for the light of day.

It's the night sequences coupled with the pitch black segments that really make this game for me. The lack of light, and the removal of your field of view really makes every moment incredibly tense. Coupled with the hectic, brutal combat, moment to moment decisions are crucial to your survival.

For an early access alpha game, Darkwood has an incredible amount of potential. I'm truly looking forward to what the devs have to offer in future iterations.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My hands were cold and clammy as I gulped silently. My watch starterd beeping. 12:00 it said, midnight. The tv screen was glaring at me for some time with the only vivid colours I can remember. My heart started to race as I was a few minutes away from my home base. I thought to myself that right now would be the best idea to trod back. Nightfall emergers and my breath becomes a bit more shorter than the other breath. I can't contain myself, I'm very anxious about this event. I doubt I'll even make it through.

The well has prompted me to drink from it, I tell myself, close the curtains and put some headphones on, it'll be fun. I did as what my head told me to do. It begun, I cornered myself on one end of the room with all beartraps hanging about. I feel nervous at the sight of these things as they might turn against me at one point and time. The growling begun. My heart was pacing faster, I mean, what could go wrong right? Well the barricaded door north of me corrected that sentence as something is chomping it's way through my doors. BANG BANG BANG" It went.

The growling was louder than before. I can't help but to hold my breathe as the events unfolded in front of me. I decided to position myself as far away as possible from the door
date: but guess what? It's not over. Just south of me the door started to get attacked. It felt weird
recommended: I was feeling neither fear nor anxiety. The mix of horrible emotions was too difficult for me to handle. "BANG!" The door on the north gave way
hoursPlayed: gave way to something so terrible words cannot explain. But alas
voteText: the bear traps teeth GRISLED the thing. By the grace of god
helpfulPercent: I cleaved the infernal being in half with my axe
votesHelpful: surprisingly with one blow it faltered
votesTotal: embracing the cold planks which I stood in. As the southern door broke
votesFunny: I see a faint light fill my room. It was daybreak.\n\nWaking up knowing tomorrow is going to be a more horrible day
commentsCount: I start my daily cycle. I'll push through this."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An amazing dark game about survival. Darkwood succeeds in creating a unique atmosphere by combining great gameplay and sound. Despite being a 2d game it can still scare you in more than enough situations. Inside the game there are plenty of hidden clues waiting for you to discover them in order to unravel the lore of this great game. All of these create an amazing experience you should not miss. I definitely recommend this game, you should buy it if you have not already, but beware, it's a hard, hard game that will haunt your dreams :).

If you enjoyed this review and found it helpful, then please consider following my curator page. Thank you!

http://store.steampowered.com/curator/10128571-SquidofLuvPlays/

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Darkwood is a deeply atmospheric, punishing adventure survival game, with a surreal and dark Eastern European theme. For being a top-down game, it has gorgeous graphics that make the most light and shadow to give the game world texture, and the visuals are backed up by excellent and skillfully used sound effects that give you a reason to turn up your speakers. Gameplay is harsh, and random, and a healthy dose of caution is required doing most anything. It's a good game to play around in the sandbox or pursue the story elements, but which ever you do, it will be a shadowy and blood-soaked nightmare of an experience. I'd recommend this game to anyone who likes horror, adventure, survival or RPG games, or any mix of them. The difficulty IS an acqired taste though, be forewarned.

So far in Early Access, I've experienced no crashes and only a few minor to moderate bugs. Darkwood is up there in the ranks of Early Access games who had their ♥♥♥♥ together before they came on Steam.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Darkwood though in early development is now one of my favorite games of all time.

Pros:
1. Scary
2. Awesome The Last Of Us-like crafting system
3. Fantastic NPC characters
4. Challenging enemies
5. Large and adventurous map
6. Awesome weapon play
7. Wolfman
8. Fun and smart puzzles and quests
9. Interactable objects
10. Barricadeable objects

Both Pro And Con:
1. Difficulty curve on enemies: I love how it's a hard game and it should stay that way but it does get frustraiting at times
2. No hunger system

Cons:
1. Missing a bit of information when you play is never said again
2. Buggy woodsaw

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My previous view on this game changed for the better :). Alpha 7 really done great for this game and its good that the game is still in developement.

pros:
- hard but rewarding
- added tutorial
- more content like crafting, better storyline npc's and monsters
- many concerns were adressed: now firearms work well and controls are more responsive
- sense of being lost

cons:
- many useless items that have no purpose usually from previous installments of the game that can confuse players
- the night mechanic was better in the past, you could choose to wander in the dark, hide near creek or in abandoned house in forest and now you NEED to stay in hideout just not to die. Now when everything in night survival is well figured out, a night is just plain boring.

Generally, if you find this game in indie bundle of some sort for 5 bucks then buy, if not then probably wait for more content.

Early Access Review

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VVS5NYv0T9g&list=PLBqXrq67D6oqISOEN5rtGT4TAkqGD3p9I

It's unbelievable how a top down perspective game can provide more tension and anxiety than a lot of first person view games. Darkwood does an incredibly job on the atmosphere, remarkable work on the sound which takes a huge part in that regard. The survival genre has grown making it more difficult to find games that stand out, Darkwood does it by delivering deep surreal experience and very, very shady. I won't say more for now to avoid spoilers.

Pros
- amazing work on the sound, even bumping at a chair provokes noises that make you cringe
- tense and scary atmosphere from the start
- there's crafting but...

Cons
- ...I would like the crafting system be more discover able"
date: as long as you have the ingredients on you
recommended: the crafting result will show up for you to click and craft"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am no horror veteran, however, I am a game vet. Darkwood was the only game that had me panicked.
It was the dead of the night.
I was hiding in my small cottage.
My door was broken down.
A 'thing' entered.
I screeched I won't let you take me!" and killed it after a wound and a bruise.
The things body was gone in the morning.
Was it a hallucination?
Or was it something that the woods had chewed up and spat out?"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

i have been eagerly awaiting this game for some time now, all the trailers made it look like an amazing horror game(this is the first trailer i saw around a year ago)

i am only a few hours in and i already restarted once because i was on day 4 and i had gotten myself killed in stupid ways every day and thus i had not even experienced the night time yet.....

on my second play i have been a LOT more careful, i looked outside with torch on the first night and was almost killed by some kind of sword wielding monster i survived by running around my house like a chicken with its head cut off(after failing to even get close enough to hit it with a torch) and even around my house until day came. then the second night after i drank water i sat in a corner next to the door to the outside in the dark and waited, listening to the creatures wander around outside no weapons except 1 Molotov and some matches and an almost out torch. then the door slowly creaked open, i quickly slammed the door closed and ran further inside and hid next to the second door, my heart literally pounding, i did not hear any footsteps, although i could hear some kind of ethereal moan.... suddenly this door too flies open, i slam it closed and see a life bar appear on the bottom of my screen i run through the third door(that i had just repaired before night fall) and i pull out my torch to get a look at whatever is hunting me, it looks like some kind of slow moving shadow creature, as i start to figure out which way i am going to escape day breaks and the creature vanishes. i don't know if i have ever been more revealed while playing a video game in my life. i had to pause and go get a glass of water to calm me down.

i am going camping tonight.... maybe i should have waited to start this game till i got back

reviewText:
Early Access Review

WHAT
this is a surreal psychological horror game where you survive the wierd world that is darkwood

STORY
the story is interesting and and quite dark ,but is just the first chapter

COMBAT
the combat is tricky at first you aren't supposed to run in and buttonmash that will get you killed faster than you can say f*ck off!!!!!". It is ment to be strategic and slow paced you attack when you have the opportunity: get one hit in
date:
gtfo and wait for another chance

DAY/NIGHT
now the biggest thing about this game that makes it interesting is the day/night cycle. In the day you scavange for supplies and fuel to keep your hideout in shape and your generator running so you can progress to the next area and hideout. At night however it varies from nothing happening at all to your furniture flying all over the place to savages breaking down your baracedes

DIFFICULTY
at first it has a steep learning curve and i would suggest watching a lets play if you are held back by this
recommended:
however if you are awesome you will just learn it through either trial and error or the wiki page in another tab while you are playing

DEVS
constent updates keeps the game alive with gameplay changes bugfixes and overhauls the dev team has done a great job with keeping it fresh and i can't wait to see the full version

THIS GAME IS AWESOME BUY IT NOW!!!!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of the best horror games i have played in a while. It's lovecraft inspired aura and atmosphere really sell this game. From masses of gaping flesh, to giant mutant pigs, to just simple insanity from within your character, this game has no lack of horror elements and even possesses sever RPG and Rogue like qualities.

There are several things i would recommend adding to this game is more of those qualities such as more improvements on the house or even things like rescuing survivors and having them help fight with you at night in your house. The desolate feel of the game hooks you in from the beginning but wears on your attention later on so some companions would really help maintain a sense of progress aswell as some inspiration to keep going.

Also the story is not lackluster by any means but once you get past a certain part of the game, it just becomes cryptic and i end up feeling unmotivated to progress through it when I find the exploration and NPC sidequest's far more engaging.

Overall 666/10 would ♥♥♥♥ pants at night again
Keep it coming
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Warning: Contains minor spoilers

Well I just barely finished the lynx quest, went through the doctors house and...

Holy crap the roots. The roots fill me with raw fear. I don't understand it, in darkwood there is monsters whose entire BODY is split apart to reveal sharp teeth. And the roots scare me more. Why? Because I don't understand them, I don't know where they come from. I don't know how to beat them. The entire underground is filled with roots. Thats what it means, and that fills me with fear. Going into the church basement is also scary. But not as scary as the roots, the fear of the unknown. And this is why Darkwood is my favorite horror game:









It has made me scared of trees.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this on a lark because I like games like Metro and the STALKER series and I wanted more survival horror in my life. I play with permadeath on because anything else is for babies and children with thyroid disorders. I went to bed frustrated last night because I couldn't manage to get into the next zone, past this cottage, and restarting was feeling tedious.

Last night I dreamt of a drowned woman chasing me, asking me if I knew how bad it must be down there that she'd claw all the way back up here? Then I awoke to an invisible presence gripping my hands and weighting me down. Then I actually woke up.

10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 1...

I have awoken in a room with a wolf, but he is a friendly wolf. He has given me some insight on the situation and told me about a crazy chicken lady who I shall seek out later but first I decided to look around my hideout to hopefully find a weapon.

10 Minutes have passed and no weapon or anything useful. I hopped out my window to look for the well. I found it moments later but something else appears to have found me, something terrifying began staring at me with it's cold bloodshot eyes. We stared for what felt like hours until it scurried in my direction. I did the only thing I could...Turn and jump through the window. I thought I would be ok but I was wrong, it followed me so I jumped out the window to the outside and hurried into the generator room. I turned it on hoping it would deter the beast...It did, or atleast my hiding skills had made it loose track of me.

A while past and I noticed it was getting dark so I headed back inside where I waited till the well was ready to be drunk.

Finally the well was drinkable so I drunk as much as I could when suddenly I heard a loud noise so I hopped back inside, ran to the generator and switched it hoping to deter whatever it was.

It's pitch black outside but my lamps are doing ok at keeping it lit inside. For safety measure I have placed a stool next to the window to make sure no one could possibly get in. I waited...And waited...

I walked around the house aimlessly when suddenly I noticed the worst thing imaginable...The lights went out...I heard some inhuman laugh or noise, whatever it was I knew it was now coming for me, in hopes my hiding skills would once work again I hid in a corner... *Creeeeeeeeek* The door went as someone entered my house. *Cshhhhhh* went the stool as someone or something walked past it. The footsteps got louder AND louder AND LOUDER until they were inches away from me. *Shinkkkk* went the blade that cut, piercing my skin. I screamed and ran for the window where I hopped out and closed the door hiding myself once again inside the generator room. 'I'm screwed' I thought as I listned for any movemnt...



I waited and waited until I noticed light beaming lightly through the hole in the wall. I went to the door and opened it...It was day...I survived...'But wait!' I thought. 'What if it was still out here?' And as thoughts raced through my mind I did the only thing I thought I could do. I ran for the chicken ladies house. I remembered it was east so I ran as fast as my shaking legs could carry me. But without focusing properly I heard the worst noise imaginable...'Cshhhh' went the sound of a few mushrooms crushing beneath my feet. 'No......' I thought. I almost began to cry but I thought that if I got to her house maybe, just maybe she will have something to help me. So I ran once again as fast as I could. I saw a structure. 'Yes YES!' I shouted. As I closed nearer my heart stopped...It was the pig place...I looked left and right furiously as I felt my legs about to give way. I turned and ran north as fast as I could but it was to no use. Within seconds my legs gave way and I fell flat on my face where I layed...To die....

Early Access Review

darkwood is a top-down horror game that idolizes usual survival elements, but this game is anything but usual whan it comes to the enviroments, chalenges and ovel-all experience. let me tell you, this game is brutal, I, being a more of an adaptive(casual <-> hardcore) gamer found that the game only stays within the player's comefort zone for a short while. during the day i was free to roam and explore (untill i found a pack of dogs) i found a very small amount of resources, and headed inside for the night. What accualy killed me was not a monser, but the fact that you need to drink form the well befor you buckle down for the night, or you will slowly die. This bothered me some as i didn't know i was supposed to fix the well, or i just didn't bother to pay attention to the warnings. I later awoke to find that i was the second say, I was disapointed to find that the buff i had worked for thorught gathering mushrooms was gone, but whatever i had found yesterday was still on me.

my accual review? this game blew me away, I was expecting allot, but not this much. the gameplay was smooth, the lighting and enviroments are perfect, and i'm considering boarding up my bedroom window out of fear of a shadow monster crawling in. I was a little unhappy at first by the pixely graphics, but it didn't bother me at all later in the game. I'm having a great time playing this game and so should you.

4.75 / 5

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThat game is awesome! It is a combination of Stalker: Shadow of Chernobyl, Amnesia and Hotline Miami. It is so atmospheric and immersive. Not only that, it is damn scary at times. I screamed more than once and not because of carefully crafted jump-scares either; these were emergent and organic scares with plenty of build-up in a distinctly non-linear world. Brilliant. The story is intriguing too. The difficulty however is the great part for me. No handholding (a decent tutorial in the form of a prologue but that’s it) and lethal enemies. It is extremely hard, which makes every victory, no matter how small, seem immense. Seriously, buy this game. There are $90 AAA titles without even a tenth of this game’s great design.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok, Misture a atmosfera de trevas e medo do desconhecido do Silent Hill, com a jogabilidade e um mundo (que quer te matar) de Don't Starve.
Resultado:
Um jogo de graficos simples, jogabilidade estabanada (pra piorar o seu medo de luta), uma história complexa e cheia de segredos, um mundo em estado apocalíptico, um sistema de habilidade ultilizando da flora de uma floresta sinistra com efeitos colaterais (que dificultam ainda mais a sua sobrevivencia).

Darkwood trás aos seus jogadores a realidade de quão frágil e instintiva uma pessoa fica em uma situação de extremo numa floresta macabra, tentando sobreviver dentre os turnos diários dentre pilhagem/Dia e sobrevivência/Noite, é notavel a dificuldade de luta nesse jogo trazendo ainda mais à realidade situacional de alguem tentando sobrreviver em  condições de fraqueza, multilação, e mutação (Se você quer um entreterimento de click/kill, não lhe recomendo esse jogo).

Recomendo pessoalmente este jogo a pessoas que procuram uma sobrevivência complexa ao terror da noite, e uma historia repleta de surpresas e atrativos macabros.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Darkwood is a top down survival game that plays like an old school GTA or Hotline Miami ableit much slower. You are a greasy hobo living in a shack and your goal is to navigate a randomly generated verdant plot of land and eventually escape it.

The games prologue is a short tutorial but frankly it doesnt do a good job of preparing you for the game. Many mechanics such as cooking, leveling up and using perks is not explained.

Visually the game is simple and draws alot of inspiration from Slender and Silent Hill for tis spooky atmosphear which it pulls off pretty well.

The sound minimal however it effectively punctuates the highs and lows of the game. The sound effect are really well done and go a long way to enhance the atmosphere.

As nice as it all sound the game is still an alpha and after playing for 11 hours it still needs a long way to go before being anywhere close to enjoyable.
While the ideas are solid the game suffers from quite a few game game breaking bugs. Crashes and black screens are common and so are various glitches which you should familirise yourself with if you intent of getting anywhere in this game.

The odds are stacked heavily against you and dying is a common and costly occurence. You are defeceless when unarmed and unless you restarded the game a few times it will a be a while before you get your first weapon.  Sadly even then your chances of remaining unscathed are pretty slim. Most enemies have either a longer reach a lunge or plain old stunlock though a flurry or blows so getting to know your enemies is important and in most cases you cant take on more than one baddy at a time.
Your weapons seem to be made of styrophoam since most of them break after every fight and rapairs or resupplies are very costly. Despite te starting vendor selling ammo for various firearms I have yet to see most of them. I have only used the double barrel shotty and the pellet gun both of which were jaringly inferior to the axe.
If you are getting the jist that this game is hard you have heard nothing yet. The game uses a day and night cycle ( aprox 15/9 irl min) During the days you forrage and complete quests and during the night you fend off baddies enmasse.
Problem is if you play the game as intended you wont last more than 2 days so you have resort to an exploit of hiding in a corner under total darkness in oder to skip the nighttime assaults.

Exploring during the day is equaly agonising because of your characters speed and stamina you barely have enough time to explore one location before heading back to your shack. Sprinting all the time is also unadvisable for the woods are densely populated by bear traps and poisonus fungi ( which you need ot harvest to level up) and if you want to venture deeper into the woods you are required to have a light source of a kind. Issue is some of the most uggliest baddies and lot interesting quest set pieces are located in the deeper woods. This leaves you spirinting though the woods blind triping over traps or takign and slow and takign a beating from a pack of hungry mosnters.

All in all after 11 hours the end is nowhere near in sight and I barely have any progress on my first quest. Before commiting yourself finnacialyl to this game the needsto be a lot of bug fixing and rebalancing done. I also urge the devs to do away with the random world generation since it add nothing to the game but frustration.

Verdict: wait for it to get better. Hopefully this will grow into a nice gem

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really want to enjoy this game, but I can't.

It is very atmospheric and does a really good job making you feel creeped out.  The character designs are so bizarre and disturbing; they fit perfectly with what this game is trying to accomplish. The mysterious and fragmented storyline will make you immersed in the Darkwood world. Exploration is extremely exciting because you never know what you will find and the constant looming threat of The Thirst and the creatures of the night will always make you feel rushed

Where this game fails is the combat. Weapons are not easy to find and tend to break too quickly. You will more than likely be forced to craft your own weapons which will consistently deplete your resources, but you need these same resources to build barricades to protect yourself at night because fighting during night is near impossible. When you do manage to craft a weapon, good luck trying to use it. Your attacks have to be extremely accurate in order to hit anything. Here is how most combat situations will go for you: You aim your attack. The enemy jumps at you, attacks you, and jumps back in half a second. You swing your weapon and miss. The enemy jumps back in, attacks you, jumps back out before you can even aim your next attack. Before you know it, you are dead and could not even land a single hit with your useless weapon.

This game seems to have so much potential, and I am excited to see where this game will go in the future, but the combat feels so broken, it isn't worth playing at the moment. I'm tired of being killed by the first enemy I encounter every time because the broken combat system doesn't give me any chance to protect myself.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I can tell all of the 'thumbs down' votes I get are fanboys who have buyers remorse but don't want to admit it, and want to think they've purchased a good game. Sorry kids, but you didn't. Everything in this review is completely accurate, so your downvotes just show your immaturity.

A game with great art style, but tarnished by the lack of thought put behind it. Everything in this game aesthetically is amazing.

However I will not recommend this game, for it is far too unfinished and completely unthoughtful with the design choice.

-The UI is just bad. Get rid of it.
-The game is far too unforgiving, and you have to complete extremely tedious tasks to survive. Oh, by the way, when nightfall hits, you must have drank from a certain well prior to nightfall, and be inside. Before nightfall.
-Days only last about 5 or so minutes, so good luck getting anything done within that amount of time.
-The story is completely scattered and difficult to follow. Most of the time it just doesn't make sense.

I had high hopes when I bought the game. It looked great in the trailer, but I'll tell you, this game is nothing like what the trailer shows. I think that's where they pull people in. I understand you would want your game to be challenging, but there's honestly just fake difficulty put into the game. When I say that, I mean the monsters are just straight up overpowered. They're faster than you, they're stronger, and they don't give up. If you don't have a chance, there's a major error in your game. Almost all of the locations in the game are copy/pasted, which makes for an extremely difficult time navigating where you have, and haven't been. The map is.. atrocious, to say the least, and completely inaccurate as to the locations of certain places. Pro tip: Don't listen to where the characters in game tell you to go to find a certain location, they literally have no idea where the place they told you to go is. I've been told that some person I was supposed to meet is East. I head East as far as the map would let me. Nothing there. Okay, I'll just back track a bit and try to broaden my sweep. Still nothing. After giving up I start to wander. I found the place all the way southwest on the map. I'm not kidding. There's so much more crap to this but I don't really feel like typing about it anymore, even giving it this much of a review is giving it too much credit.

Bottom line: The game is crap, design is crap, very cool art style, devs are crap (Meaning they almost never update the game, and when they do, they are miniscule updates that almost always wipe your progress even when they say it won't).

Don't buy this game. It's nowhere near worth what they're asking for. I've seen tighter free-to-play games than this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game cant even be considered Alpha.

- Graphic are atrocious even for an Indie game. The character seems to be made out of 4 pixels....
- Bugs. True its an early access alpha and things will get ironed out eventually, but there are some really severe bugs like completely wrong quest descriptions Items duplicating or disappearing in Inventory...
- Nothing to do. You can craft stuff, but you will mostly not have the materials to do so, and even if you had them... there is no real reason to craft anything besides weapons. (Since they break very fast). No useful exploring, no quest hunting nothing.
- Nights are boring to annoying. While the first night is scary, this fades out fast and will turn into boredom (means you go in the kitchen, making coffee while the night passes) or get you annoyed since it interrupts the game flow.
- No character developement. Skills seem to be quite useless, and you will lose them pretty fast anyway (you lose all character progression on death).

Only positive thing about the game so far is the atmosphere. Dark, Moody, Scary.
At least for an hour or so until all the negative points take over....

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing Darkwood for a couple of days now and I have to say, as a survival horror fan, this game is refreshing. It is DIFFICULT,so don't go into it thinking it'll ease you into anything. It won't. You don't get a lot of supplies, you have limited time to wander from your safehouse to find new locations and your map is elementary at best. You'll often be completely lost wandering around the woods, and that's part of what makes the game so scary, especially when the sun is going down and you can't remember where your safehouse is.

The other night, I sat in the dark with my one light on as my generator was running, and heard dogs outside the house. Suddenly, the dogs started yelping. something was KILLING them. My lights went out, i turned on my torch, and this shambling dude comes up to me with a stick, moaning. I got a couple of good hits on him and he ran, while shadows suddenly surrounded me in my lack of light....and then bam. Morning.

Seriously one of the most tense games I've played. I can't wait to see how it turns out when it is out of alpha and complete!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Purchased this game on release and have been impressed by it each and every time I have played it. It is a tense and terrifyingly surreal world full of nasty creatures and interesting little treasures. Exploring the world and doing your best to survive offers players an unforgetable experience and atmosphere that really does get you hooked.
Even with it being an early access title there is a lot of content to enjoy and the support by the developers at Acid Wizard really has been fantastic and is very encouraging for what is to come in the future.
This, along with the great support and care from its developers have made Darkwood a game I have not regretted purchasing for one minute!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tl;DR: Dark. Scary. Unforgiving. Awesome.

I've played a few hours when Alpha 2.0 was out. This game has really surprised me, in a good sense. It looks really promising in its current state.
It's really hard, you are never spoonfed and learn by mistakes (most of them will kill you). Your highest priority is survival: gathering resources, crafting items and weapons to save you from the horrors of the night in the woods. Trust me, there's nothing like hiding in a corner of your house, in the dark, hearing something  killing all the weaker creatures outside then bashing into your barricaded doors, moaning and growling.
The characters are quite memorable. Even with few dialogue lines they have, I felt that no one in the woods should be trusted. They're all hiding something. The protagonist is just as strange and sick, having to quench his deadly thirst from the well every night.
The graphics are lovely. Nothing too fancy, but almost every location looks like it was carefully crafted. I got that feel of presence while being in the woods. Oh, and the world is randomly generated, so every new playthrough means a new scheme of your survival.
