reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright then, first of all: It's an early access game so i recommend this game after it got out of early access cause the bugs are then fixed. But hey, your choice to buy it. I recommend it actually even in early access. Why? Because it has the feeling you're like walking alone, through the woods with wild dogs/wolves and tribesmen.

Atmosphere is like: What was that? Every time you hear a bump in your hideout that will be like your reaction and look around like crazy cause of...

First Person visibility: Yes first person visibility on a bird view game. It's like playing it first person but much different. Makes it more eerie.

Then the combat system... you need to get used to that as you need to ready your weapon at first. Also: Missing is going take a huge chunk of your health. So try and master the combat skills in this game cause it is essential for SURVIVAL!

In overall i think it's a really realistic survival with a bit of a twist and storyline!

Almost forgot it: there is a storyline they do not really inform you about in the game.

Very fun game. The game sucks you in and there's no easy way of getting out. The smallest things can scare you in this game. There is no pre-made map. There is a map however but you don't know where you are on it. You must use your surroundings to figure out where you are, and if you get lost, then you're going to have an excrutiating game getting back to your safehouse.
Nights are going to be next to impossible to survive especially when you first start out. You are going to have to be perfect with your timing if you are to fight monsters with a melee weapon. Guns are extremely hard to come by and even when you get them you're not going to want to use it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is one of those moments I am proud of being Polish. This game is superb even now, despite the bugs, and I got a feeling, that around Beta this game will be just as astonishing as a game can be. Schizophrenic flavour, unique characters, perfect gameplay combining Roguelike, Survival Horror, RPG and Adventure. And scares. Those scares. Sounds, views, dialogues, the true feel of being in haunted, abandoned, and madhouse place. This is, in my opinion, best horror game since long time. And a lot of additional flavour for Slavic/PL players, hidden in the context, locations, or items - I love it, like reading one of Pilipiuk's books.  Keep going, Acid Wizard - you are true artists at work. I am waiting for Alpha 2.0, and replaying 1.3 Campaign once again :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been waiting to play this game the moment I watched the first trailers when it was posted on Greenlight, and while I am disappointed that it's in Early Access now, I am happy to say that it's well worth the money even to play the alpha.

The atmosphere is thick and tense, aided by detailed graphics and terrifying sound design, the interface is smooth and intuitive, and the setting and characters are both unnerving and interesting to the point of keeping you coming back for hours.

The only complaints I have with this game as of now is that there are at least two progression-blocking bugs I've come across, as well as some dodgy optimization issues dealing with level generation and fps, but I understand that Early Access leaves some room for improvement, and I'm actually pleasantly surprised that the game is as polished as it is currently.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nthere are a few loading bugs if you try to just quit and  come back later less freaked out. Also on one of the maps I had a phasing chomper. I tried to lead him to a bear trap but as soon as he got it it he disappeared...then when I walked where he bit me he would phase back in and attack me again. So far these are the only bugs. Oh and not that Im complaining but Im on day 15 mainly because somewhere the game glitched and stopped spawning monsters at night around day 9. I found that light is your best friend and worst enemy but you can use it as a lure. I turn my generator on every night and hide in a corner and watch the monsters all swarm the room and circle the light. just hold still and they won't hurt you....move the slightest and your dead.....well you're dead if they circle out to far also. Drop all your gas in the generator room. don't bother storing it...you are very limited for hoading and, if you can, hoard as many stacks of boards and nails as you can find. I had to fend off a house attack by running and repairing doors and rebarricading them. Also FIND A WATCH..OMG...it helps more than having a flashlight or torch. The game is low quality but replay, story, creep factor, and challenge are way high I would like to see some more abilities come from this as I have maxed out and now need 97,452ml for a dose. ( I assume its impossible to get, but I'm gonna try). For those that want story play without permadeath (wish you didn't lose abilities for getting hosed though) for those that want a knuckle whitening challenge where you need to flee more than fight...permadeath...its sooo frustrating and freakin scary (if you play with the proper gamma settings DON'T CHEAT!).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The prologue really set the stage for me as I was already needing a change of pants due to how scary the ambience of this game is.
The sound in this game is absolutely crazy. From the swing of an axe to the footsteps of an intruder in you house keep you on edge at all times. The second thing which really hit the scare factor for me was the vision cone. Not being able to see all around you keeps you spinning around, scanning the area like a radar whenever you hear a sound you didnt make yourself.

My first night in was pretty traumatic. I sat in the dark corner of my house as I listened to god knows what murder a stray dog just outside my window. The next thing I'm hearing is this murderous creature climb through the window into my home. So I sat, waiting for the beartrap I set to go off, heart beating, eyes never blinking, axe held above my head; ready to crush whatever might be infront of me. And then it found me. A crazed human like creature with a spear. It growled like an angry zombie and we traded a couple of blows before it finally wouldn't get back up. I looted some pills from it and went back to my corner and waited for sunrise.
The next day I went out scavenging and was killed by wild pigs. Permadeath was on. 10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't usually write Reviews for Games, but I had to make an exception for Darkwood. I backed this title on Indigogo originally, and early on was drawn to the idea. Every other game I have backed was a disappointment but not this one! Even for being in alpha state, the game already succeeds at drawing you into the creepy and somtimes terrying world of Darkwood. My review follows, but for those that do not wish to read TL;DR: A monster started chasing me, so I sprinted towards my house. I lost him, but ran into a mushroom and died. 10/10

Gameplay
You wake up in your safehouse after the prologue. A man with a dog face waits for you, and gives you some basics. He gives you some clues about the mysterious Dogtag you have on you, and points you towards the Chicken Lady" to the west. From here you're on your own. Your main objective is to follow the clues
date: but along the way you may follow a trail or a strange noise and before you know it you're exploring the world. Littered along the woods are items and crafting supplies
recommended: letting you make some basic survival supplies. When it starts to get dark
hoursPlayed: the thirst comes forcing you to return to the safehouse where a well keeps you alive for another day. But the day doesn't end here
voteText: now you can cook the items you found infected with whatever is eating up the woods. This results in essence
helpfulPercent: which act as experience points. When you've collected enough essence
votesHelpful: you get to select from a list of skills. They range from nice to incredibly useful
votesTotal: but somtimes a player must also take a downside to balance out the power. When you die
votesFunny: you return to your home with your equipped items slighty damaged
commentsCount: all your essence items stolen and back at level 1
column16: so you should think twice before storming into a fight. Health is pretty basic
column17:
but there is also stamina which is used by using items or running.

Controls
The controls are interesting. Most of the game is played with the mouse and WASD. Items that have more than one action accessible to the player have a context menu that is brought up. You can sprint with shift and open the inventory/crafting menu with tab. There is also a map (m) and a journal (j). For me the controls felt fairly smooth and natural."

I have just purchased this game and am enjoying the experience so far! It has fantastic atmosphere, and keeps me on edge, but not quite scared enough to stop playing and cradle myself in a corner. I do have to turn up the brightness, because MAN when they say Darkwood, they really mean DARKwood.

I found that the prologue could be a little vague in finding your way around at first, but otherwise a great exploration game! This has been one of the few games that I am quite impressed with for an early access. You already get a good experience for what you're paying.

It seems to me that this is a truly a unique experience, and I can't wait to see how this continues to develop!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nMy first horrifying experience in Darkwood happened on the second or third night. I had just sprinted all the way back to my some-what fortified base, took a drink from a well, and made my way inside. I began shutting all the doors I could, and got into a room I had began to call my safe-haven. The two windows in that room were boarded up, but there was one thing I had left untouched... the door. The previous nights had shown me, or I had thought had shown me, that I could just push a dresser infront of it and it would all go peachy. So I left it that way. reviewText:
Early Access Review

At first some points and after that a retelling of an awesome ingame night.

The game is early access and thus has some issues here and there. One that happened the most to me was getting stuck in the inventory animation, not being able to move anymore and one time the only control it accepted was moving, with everything else not responding. So be advised about that if you buy it right now.

Other than that: It's great. I can't remember what other game nailed the sounds that good and was able to get the creepy athmosphere across from a top down 2d perspective.

Another thing that might turn people off is the difficulty:
Lots and lots of dying. Be it animals, monsters, stepping into poisonous areas or mushroom patches and so on.
Your accessibility to weapons is limited and to good weapons even more.
It doesn't help that every time you die you lose all your food (which is used to progress your skills) and every equipable item loses durability with most of them being either rare or frail to start with.


Now to my story inside the game:

Stumbling around in the dark, hearing wooden doors in the distant creak or small twigs in the wood snap, only to turn around and see that there is allready a birdheaded monster standing behind you.

Rain and Thunderstorms with different sounds depending if you are inside or outside and a view cone that adapts to the light (ie. if you are in a totally dark room, you basically see ♥♥♥♥).

I was in the room of my HQ cabin, stood in a corner to wait out the night, one single light in front of me that could always turn off if the generator outside loses fuel and aside from the 3 barricaded windows there is one door, which I barricaded with a crate. Distand wolfhowls (that originate from actual NPC wolves) and then the horrifying creaking of the floor in the next room....something is inside the cabin.

I waited it out but then it happened, the crate moves. someone pushes against the door, slowly but steady and moves the crate with that. Then silence, the door opened and one of the birdskullheaded monsters walks into the room towards me. stops, looks around, seemingly doesn't see me and turns around, walking up and down the room, repeating the same routine 2 more times before FINALLY leaving.

Pretty ♥♥♥♥ing intense and the amazing part: It's top down 2D graphics that are able to build that kind of athmosphere.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nVery well made for Alpha, can't wait for updates for the game! If you are looking for a game that will give you a few  small jump scares, this is it. A very casual horror.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nNot many games have the ability to disturb me. Sure, I can fall for jumpscares sometimes, but this game... this game isn't about jumpscares. In this game, all of it's scaring-ability is directly presented to you with a build up, which is most evident when night comes. This is one of those rare games where nighttime is actually terrifying like they claim (looking at you Minecraft and Don't Starve). During the night, you have to hunker down in your little log cabin and essentially pray for the morning light. Problem is that when the sun falls, demons come from the darkness and you're able to hear them as they attempt to penetrate your shoddily-crafted barricades. In one situation, I had barricaded a window and blocked off the two doors with a stool and a dresser, thinking that was sufficient. However, as I passed time in the pitch blackness of my room (generator had gone out), listening to the hellish shrieks, moans and snarls of the hunters lurking about outside, I encountered a new sound. A door opening and the sound of an object being shoved. The hairs on my arms stood up straight, my pulse quickened, chest tightened, and, in the darkness of the room, something else was with me. Going against everything my common sense was telling me, I lit a flare to get a look. When I spotted that disfigured demon casually shambling into my sanctuary my heart skipped a beat. Luckily, he hadn't seen me and I was able to quickly dispatch of him. This is how the scares in DARKWOOD are presented. You know they're coming, and the buildup to them is just as painful as the climax. Other than that, DARKWOOD presents a very intriguing plot and contains some of the coolest and most stylized NPCs around (I stared at the wolf merchant and the violin boy for a good five minutes). Overall, DARKWOOD shows great promise in its early access stage, and from this point, there's no where to go but up. Buy it if you don't mind the bugs that comes with early access or put it on your wishlist for later, because this game is 100% fantastic.

I am SO glad that I bought this game. It is SO scary.

You're probably thinking, How is a top-down game scary? You can just see everything."

No. No you can't.

Early Access Review

Though it's only been a year since the crowdfunding campaign for it, Darkwood is already shaping up to be one of my most eagerly anticipated games.

The controls can be a little hard to get used to, but the atmosphere is amazing and sound design is just that perfect mix of creepy and effective.

If this is what they can do for just the alpha, I can only imagine the (engaging) horrors that are in store for the full release

Very Creepy and Atmosphereic. Hard as hell though, the only weapon you'll have most of the time playing being the infamous plank with nails, while having to face monsters that can two hit kill you. Only complaints I have with the game: weapons are too hard to find along with sources of illumination.

BUT hell man this is an AWESOME game, totally worth the money for me right now. Ive had plenty of scary moments, one of which I will share with you now...

Night of the 2nd day. Doing pretty good. Got myself a alcohol bandage, a savage's twig, plenty of nails and boards, and some gasoline for the generator of the safehouse. I had just finished barricading the last window of the house when I see the well activate, telling me that night has offically begun. I quickly run outside via the side door and take a drink, then go back inside and barricade the door with my last remaining nails. I stand back to admire my haniwork, but my bright mood is cut short by the blabbering of a savage approaching the house. I snap out of my safe" feeling and run back to the kitchen oven and sit in the corner to await the arrival of daylight.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Darkwood is by far the most interesting game I've played since Project Zomboid. It's creepy, thick atmosphere is only outmatched by it's simple but complex mechanics. With a different game world generated for each playthrough (and perma-death as an option for the true rogue player), terrifying creatures, barricading system, survivalist mechanics and it's eerie and very much fleshed out characters, this is definitely one of the true old-school hard and scary games out there.

You might not like this game if you are into constant firefights, being an OP character, or a lot of in game guidance.
This game tends to drop you right into it and you have to figure out the best way to survive for yourself.

10/10 and I NEVER give these ratings
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of THE most atmospheric games I have ever played. Day five found me locked in my hideout, thinking I was safe, only to have a beast round the corner and rip out my throat. I lost everything, my skills, and my mutated items.

This game is brutal and unforgiving. And I love it.

Now there are a few things, seeing as it is an alpha.

Sometimes, this game is TOO unforgiving. Dying means you do lose everything, without the chance to get it back. And because resources don't respawn, you're gimped for the rest of that section if you ever die in the middle of the night, making it increasingly harder to restock and regain your footing. You also take ALL ITEM DURABILITY DAMAGE which is mean on top of losing all of your skills.

It needs a few balancing tweaks, but other than that, this game has major potential.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Despite its early access status (meaning it isn't a full game right now), you'll love the atmosphere as you explore the forest during the day, before cowering and wetting yourself in the claustrophobic darkness at night.

Make sure you barricade yourself into your home at night, or you'll meet a horrible and swift end.

The best survival horror in years. If you've ever loved the early Resident Evils and Silent Hills, and if you're a fan of Amnesia and the like, just throw down your £12 for Darkwood right now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Despite being early access, this game already has a lot going for it. The oppressive atmosphere really helps to immerse players into the game, while the overall difficulty really cements the fact that here in the forest the player is not the most dangerous thing lurking in the darkness. The gameplay is fairly simple at the moment; from a top-down view the player walks around the game world, their line of site represented by a visual cone, when the character is not facing something like, say, a searchable pile of rubble or a wandering enemy or NPC, they disappear from the game map, though you can still hear them. This is used to quite terrifying effect if your power goes out and a monster breaks into your home, as your field of view shrinks tremendously, or when you need to craft a weapon or use something from your inventory, as your field of vision disappears while your character has to rummage around inside his pack. Melee combat is fairly simple but rewarding, and good timing is key to surviving any unavoidable confrontation. I've seen gameplay of firearms, but have yet to personally acquire one myself.

The story, at this point, isn't all that clear to me. The bare bones of it is that the player character is stranded within a forest of the Soviet Block, apparently after some form of horrific mind and body altering plague outbreak, however, this is certainly not just another generic and then zombies" story. The creatures and characters you will meet have been transformed or changed in very strange and terrifying ways. The current goal of the player seems to be to find their way out of the forest

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played this for about 10 or more hours before the alpha 2.1 update. Really thouroughly enjoyed it, although as a survival horror where punishment is so severe, its slow going. Lack of story in these parts can end up making it a chore just to play. As well as complete save wipes with every early access update and game mechenics changing to the point where I have to relearn how to play every time, I am going to wait until the game is fully released and polished before I put many valueble hours into playing it from start to finish. Aside from that I quite like the survival aspects, the environmental interaction and the fact that you have to experiment with things. Be prepared for trial and error and a massive learning curve, although this is where all the fun is. When you do progress or things go right, it feels really good as a change from the brutal world. Unique and unlike most top down or horror genres. Definitely worth a play and should be on your wishlist at the very least.

TL;DR
Pros:
-Unique
-Rewarding gameplay in contrast to brutal punishment
-So far has a very good story line, explained through the world and actions as well as NPC dialogue
-Interesting
-CRAFTING!
-BASES!
-Survival horror is very well done

Cons:
-Slow game play can lead to slow story progression and thus it can become dry
-Death really sucks
-Early access updates wipe your save
-Sometimes cluncky controls

Worth a buy 7.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Darkwood:
8/10

+ Challenging game.
+ Always has a scary atmosphere, even if it's light outside.
+ the Don't Stay in the dark at Night Idea is amazing ;)

- U might die alot if u just started ;) (atleast i did)
- Still a bit empty somethimes. But it's still early access so i don't complain that much about that.

Would recommend this game to people who love to Survive in a Dark Forest, where u can't get out ;)
It's a Challenging Game, especially when you just Started playing.
You always have to go back to your house every night, to drink from that well, this might seem annoying, but i actually like it ;)
I recommend this game not only for the people who like either horror or survival. but i recommend this game for everybody!! ;), it's challenging, always a bit spooky because you dont know what to expect. And has a funny story behind it (also some NPC stories added to it.)

Good game! I'm happy it's in my library ;)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe creepy atmosphere of this game will have the player looking in every direction.  Each sound or artsy detail comes together to create a surreal horror experience.  Although the game itself is not completely terrifying in the way that a game such as Outlast might be, it's difficult to deny this game won't cause your heart to beat slightly faster.  The game's intensity also adds a lot to the atmosphere and gameplay.  I constantly find myself running to blockade doors in the midst of terror and panic.  Another great aspect of this game is the fact that they are updating it.  For example, initially I had problems differentiating day and night; however, a somewhat recent update has brightened day and seemingly darkened the night.  Overall, I have thoroughly enjoyed my experience with this game.  Whether tension, horror, or retro-style RPG's are your thing, you will find something enjoyable about this game.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The prologue really set the stage for me as I was already needing a change of pants due to how scary the ambience of this game is.
The sound in this game is absolutely crazy. From the swing of an axe to the footsteps of an intruder in you house keep you on edge at all times. The second thing which really hit the scare factor for me was the vision cone. Not being able to see all around you keeps you spinning around, scanning the area like a radar whenever you hear a sound you didnt make yourself.

My first night in was pretty traumatic. I sat in the dark corner of my house as I listened to god knows what murder a stray dog just outside my window. The next thing I'm hearing is this murderous creature climb through the window into my home. So I sat, waiting for the beartrap I set to go off, heart beating, eyes never blinking, axe held above my head; ready to crush whatever might be infront of me. And then it found me. A crazed human like creature with a spear. It growled like an angry zombie and we traded a couple of blows before it finally wouldn't get back up. I looted some pills from it and went back to my corner and waited for sunrise.
The next day I went out scavenging and was killed by wild pigs. Permadeath was on. 10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't usually write Reviews for Games, but I had to make an exception for Darkwood. I backed this title on Indigogo originally, and early on was drawn to the idea. Every other game I have backed was a disappointment but not this one! Even for being in alpha state, the game already succeeds at drawing you into the creepy and somtimes terrying world of Darkwood. My review follows, but for those that do not wish to read TL;DR: A monster started chasing me, so I sprinted towards my house. I lost him, but ran into a mushroom and died. 10/10

Gameplay
You wake up in your safehouse after the prologue. A man with a dog face waits for you, and gives you some basics. He gives you some clues about the mysterious Dogtag you have on you, and points you towards the Chicken Lady" to the west. From here you're on your own. Your main objective is to follow the clues
date: but along the way you may follow a trail or a strange noise and before you know it you're exploring the world. Littered along the woods are items and crafting supplies
recommended: letting you make some basic survival supplies. When it starts to get dark
hoursPlayed: the thirst comes forcing you to return to the safehouse where a well keeps you alive for another day. But the day doesn't end here
voteText: now you can cook the items you found infected with whatever is eating up the woods. This results in essence
helpfulPercent: which act as experience points. When you've collected enough essence
votesHelpful: you get to select from a list of skills. They range from nice to incredibly useful
votesTotal: but somtimes a player must also take a downside to balance out the power. When you die
votesFunny: you return to your home with your equipped items slighty damaged
commentsCount: all your essence items stolen and back at level 1
column16: so you should think twice before storming into a fight. Health is pretty basic
column17:
but there is also stamina which is used by using items or running.

Controls
The controls are interesting. Most of the game is played with the mouse and WASD. Items that have more than one action accessible to the player have a context menu that is brought up. You can sprint with shift and open the inventory/crafting menu with tab. There is also a map (m) and a journal (j). For me the controls felt fairly smooth and natural."

I have just purchased this game and am enjoying the experience so far! It has fantastic atmosphere, and keeps me on edge, but not quite scared enough to stop playing and cradle myself in a corner. I do have to turn up the brightness, because MAN when they say Darkwood, they really mean DARKwood.

I found that the prologue could be a little vague in finding your way around at first, but otherwise a great exploration game! This has been one of the few games that I am quite impressed with for an early access. You already get a good experience for what you're paying.

It seems to me that this is a truly a unique experience, and I can't wait to see how this continues to develop!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nMy first horrifying experience in Darkwood happened on the second or third night. I had just sprinted all the way back to my some-what fortified base, took a drink from a well, and made my way inside. I began shutting all the doors I could, and got into a room I had began to call my safe-haven. The two windows in that room were boarded up, but there was one thing I had left untouched... the door. The previous nights had shown me, or I had thought had shown me, that I could just push a dresser infront of it and it would all go peachy. So I left it that way. But little did I know, it wouldn't go as planned on this night. About halfway through the night, as I'm backed into a corner scared half to death of all the noises coming from outside, I begin to hear, rrrrrrrnnnnnnnn!" It sounded like the dresser I had infront of the un-barricaded door was being pushed. So

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is fairly simple, and very interesting, reminiscent of old flash games, but much more polished even for an alpha. While some have complained about the game not giving you any sort of direction or instruction, I find that to be the farthest thing from the truth. The game tells you exactly where to go. Loot is abundant, objectives are clear, and enemies are not too many but not too few (until night). The game is definitely worth a play, and as it sees updates, it looks like it can only get better. The game does present some major issues so far, however.

You cannot escape dogs. They are too fast. Either you fight them or you die, or avoid them if you have the skill. Fighting them can prove difficult early on as it may be easy to make nail boards, but those nails and boards are also important for barricading your home's windows, which keeps you safer longer and reduces line of sight, keeping you hidden easier. It would make a lot more sense if we were at least able to use our fists. If any of us were to be attacked by a dog, I feel like we'd fight back. Most of the enemies are extremely tough as well. Natives have obscene reach that is very hard to counter. Best to just find a gun, which can take some time. You're best taking on enemies (if you really have to fight) one at a time, as the majority of the enemies are more than twice as fast as you, have superior reach, and an infinite amount of stamina, while you can only sprint and swing for so long before they're chewing your heels off.  Most natives can, however, be outrun. Stamina conservation is key.

Speaking of fighting back, it cannot be done at night, plain and simple. You can barricade everything in your house, everything, and sit quietly with the lights off, not making a sound. Eventually, a big baddy is gonna knock down your doors/barricades, let a pack of wolves in, and eat you for a midnight snack, as if it knew you were there the whole time. Alternatively, you can use what precious fuel you find to fuel your generator, to keep your lights on. While this offers amazing lighting that rivals even daytime light, it only makes it easier to watch yourself get eaten by the mob of enemies. While I understand the game is meant to make you feel unsafe, alone, and scared, it's very frustrating when fighting back is so hard.

Aside from these issues, I can't think of anything else that's wrong with this game. Maybe the economy needs some balancing, or perhaps combat needs to be tweaked, reworked a little even, but otherwise the game at its best moments is fun and genuinely challenging. The atmosphere is terrifying, which is difficult to achieve with a top down game.

Play it, help further development.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Despite being early access, this game already has a lot going for it. The oppressive atmosphere really helps to immerse players into the game, while the overall difficulty really cements the fact that here in the forest the player is not the most dangerous thing lurking in the darkness. The gameplay is fairly simple at the moment; from a top-down view the player walks around the game world, their line of site represented by a visual cone, when the character is not facing something like, say, a searchable pile of rubble or a wandering enemy or NPC, they disappear from the game map, though you can still hear them. This is used to quite terrifying effect if your power goes out and a monster breaks into your home, as your field of view shrinks tremendously, or when you need to craft a weapon or use something from your inventory, as your field of vision disappears while your character has to rummage around inside his pack. Melee combat is fairly simple but rewarding, and good timing is key to surviving any unavoidable confrontation. I've seen gameplay of firearms, but have yet to personally acquire one myself.

The story, at this point, isn't all that clear to me. The bare bones of it is that the player character is stranded within a forest of the Soviet Block, apparently after some form of horrific mind and body altering plague outbreak, however, this is certainly not just another generic and then zombies" story. The creatures and characters you will meet have been transformed or changed in very strange and terrifying ways. The current goal of the player seems to be to find their way out of the forest

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me first say that if you are not fond of hard games, this may not be the game for you. The game has a rather steep learning curve for first timers... But for those who brave it and learn from it, I assure you that you will thuroughly enjoy this game. Suffice it to say, your character may die in this game... perhaps a lot in your first play through. Though, like dark souls, every 'death' is a learning experience, and this game rewards persistance.

Matched with an environment as creepy as its well-told story, the Devs have truly outdone themselves with the creation of compelling (and very disturbing) characters shown in a world full of danger. You will quickly need to learn how to survive and, for the sake of maintaining the resorces you find, find tricks to keeping your character alive.

The fact that this game is still in Alpha is, for me, among the most exciting factors of the experience. In and of itself, the game has run without flaw from me, save a few minor easy-to-avoid/get past glitches that I have seen in many slelf-proclaimed 'finished' games. Just so, the thought of MORE being added to this game in every aspect pleases me greatly. This is a game well worth both attention and support... And heck, why not have a GREAT time playing what they have thus far while doing both of these things?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I recently moved into a new home about 2 weeks before the Darkwood alpha was released and I was not quite used to the sounds that my house or my cats would make at night yet.

On my first night in Darkwood I backed into a corner of a room and nervously clutched a wooden board with nails. Standing there, all I could do was shift my vison around the room in a vein attempt to spot the source of the noises which I could not identify. Luckily nothing broke in and I continued on, repeating another uneventfull but nervous night in a corner listening to the creaks of wood floors, the sound of a struggle ending with a dog's whimper, and a deep gurgling sound that seemed to be moving around my dilapidated sanctuary.

On my third night in game I had found a few bear traps and placed them around my hide out in the hopes of killing anything that would be foolish enough to ambush me. Lo and behold, something started to beat down my door and I sat there clutching my half broken board hoping it would be enough to protect me from whatever was coming to get me. Just as the last sliver of life was torn away from my feeble defenses one of my cats burst thru my door and jumped onto my shoulder. I cried out and knocked the cat to the floor who then bolted out of the room.

I sat there staring at the screen, still breathing heavily, while my groggy eyed wife slowly pushed open the door to my study to ask what had happened. I turned off my monitor, reasured her nothing was wrong, and followed her to bed. I then stared at the ceiling with my eyes darting around our darkened room at every unfamiliar noise. She awoke 6 hours later with me sitting in a chair in the corner of the room watching the door and windows.

10/10 - I will continue to lose many nights of sleep over this game. I advise you to lock your door before playing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As an old-school gamer from the 80's, I've always had a soft-spot for 2D games - Especially if they cover my favourite genre, survival horror.

Dark Wood may not hold your hand or throw an informative intro your way, but you learn enough to understand the situation and environment very early - And it's not a pleasant environment... Not pleasant at all...

After being *rescued* by a mysterious *Doctor* during a supposed viral based epidemic (or so we're led to believe, at least in your own mind), you are thrust into a decrepid world where 'surviving' is key. Doing so requires crafting, making the choice between fight or flee, setting up a stronghold/barricade that will need to be prepared in order to fend off the creepy creatures that lurk in the night, and build your character enough that they may eventually brave deeper into the horrible world. Materials will be needed, weapons are mandatory, so there will be no bunkering down for days and hoping things go away - You will have to go out into that awful world - And there is no compass to direct you.

Dark Wood is a desperate experience, from sprinting from a quest location towards your home, trying to get to safety before night rolls over the forest, to scavanging during the day only to be met by angry wildlife or vicious humanoids who are far from human.

NPC's will open up quests or information when you bring them specific items, yet none of them can be considered 'normal' by any stretch. You can also opt to kill them in cold-blood and ransack their homes, if you are that way inclined. One way or the other, survival is paramount, while exploring and partaking in quests is up to you.

The experience as a whole is not so much terrifying as it is permanently creepy, from corpses and destruction dotted all around the random map, to cowering in the corner of your fortified base while monsters roam outside (or even inside) your 'safehouse' while you cry and pray for morning to rise.

If you're a fan of the 2D style and enjoy crafting/barricade based survival horror, with a dirty creepy world to explore and the simple fact that running is a VERY valid option over fighting for your life, then you'll love Dark Wood.

I'll be watching the growth of this game with interest and can't wait to see what else it adds into the mix.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Darkwood goes off a very lesser followed road for a horror game.
Instead of your average jump scares and cheap sound effects, the game will take it to a whole new level of what truly can be lurking in the dark.

Personally a few things I very much like about the game so far has been the Sound. Sound is practically everything in a game besides the basic functionalities, in Darkwood, if you hear that twig snap, that means either you, or something else has just walked over it. You hear that thing that went bump in the night? Odds are it's something that very much would like to see you deceased. This was a trait that keeps me on edge when playing and definitely caught my attention during my time playing it.

The overall Graphics is simplistic in design, yet complex and very well thought-out. Instead of making the game a simple First-Person or even a normal third-person game. The Acid Wizards took it up a notch by using a top-down view of your character. Trees are very detailed in perspective and as you hover your mouse over them, they will disappear as your character gains vision to that specific area, leaving other areas not in your field of view cone covered by a dense brush of trees and other foliage, this makes the game very unique as it can leave you unaware of what might be hiding underneath that treeline you have come across and very may well be your final mistake.

Keeping an eye on this game as since the initial 1.0 Alpha version it has come a very long way from then and the developers have introduced many more features to it, let alone improving overall performance and enjoyability. However it should be noted heavily that as the game states, it is very unforgiving and one wrong move can easily spell your doom.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Every time I play this game, I run the intro. And it scares me every time, even though it's scripted and I know every second of it by heart.

And that's before the actual game even begins.

Don't let the weird top-down aspect turn you off of this one, or the Early Access tag, either. The actual game may often put more emphasis on survival in this survival horror, and YES, it has CRAFTING too, but it is still easily of of the best actually scary horror games to date  ( though it could be said that it has an edge, what with so many horror games today not being even slightly scary ).

Despite the Early Access, there is still a solid game here, even in its Alpha. These guys aren't showing any signs of leaving this game in the dust either, but I personally would happily pay what they're asking just for the game they have now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game. You may be thinking typical survival/crafting horror game at first glance, but it is so much more than this. Deeply atmospheric due to a combination of great graphical style and audio. Even though the game is early access, it's got a tonne of features and already feels like a full game (how early access should be).

Well made procedural world generation means you never get bored of the game. It's a tonne of fun just exploring the world.

Developers consistently adding lots of new content and seem enthusiastic about the game.

Would recommend.

Nothing really Conny.


This game is great, just dont buy this game if you dont like Eerie/Scary and unforgiving Games. i quit ammnesia in 10 miniutes it was so Scary/Eerie.. Yeah.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Difficult to explain in words...
Working to be a masterpiece..
This game is intense on so many levels--from the characters and scenery to the sounds of the night. It is in alpha at the moment but it has HIGH potential. This game is High Priority on my updates as I am eager to every fix and add-on brought into the picture. If you are into isometric games like Diablo, this may tickle your fancy. But it is by no means a dungeon-crawler. This game combines mystery and horror with adventure and wonder.

Turn up the volume..
Turn off the lights...
Enjoy :)

Alpha 6.1
Coming along nicely; lighting is improved and there's gamepad support. Animations look a bit better and some changes have been implemented to level out the gaming. Looking great, guys. If you're timid on Early Access games, hold off for full release but if you like to see features change and improve over time, I'd grab it now ;)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nHoly Balls....who could've imagined a top-down view could be so terrifying. Creative and intricate design, off putting landscapes, unsettling and restless nights. I've played it inconsistentely, and with every new update, I've had to restart the game to get the new content. By all means it's good, but loses it's appeal with constant changes again and again. I do recommend it whole heartedly, but to be patient for its final release. I still enjoy it now, but would like some stability as well. Some additions aren't brilliant as of now and hopefully will improve in the future. I don't know when the official release will be, I just hope Darkwood fulfilles the anticipation.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A wonderfully dark and satisfying atmosphere.
The audio in this game is one of the highlights its almost as important as your viewing distance, alerting you to the many interesting creatures, in this thriller survival game.
Run, fight, sit there and cry as night approaches. Each choice you make can be your last as you cross through the Dark Wood.
This is a great Early Access game, plenty of content already, and a compelling story to keep you interested in what’s going on. I recommend this game to anyone who is tired of the usually games on the market and want to get a different experience while gaming.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is a genuine horror which makes it stand out so much from the rest.
From the graphics to the literature and down to the very gameplay it's an extremely promising gem to look forward to.

tl;dr
gud graphic
gud sound
gud gameplay
gud narrative
zero jumpscares
pure atmospheric horror

The graphics make the game so aesthetically beautiful no matter what environment you're in, the little animations that brings it to life contribute greatly to the immersion.
At a few points in the game there will be some narrative to describe the environment beyond the 2D top-down view and it does so in a poetic way that it doubles up with the graphics and really gives you the feeling of a realistic atmosphere.
Sounds you hear at night; the echoing of moving furniture and stomping around indoors, the distant yelping from dogs being attacked by God knows what, and the music that plays during the morning segments.
Being so afraid of what may be out there that you cower in a corner or lock yourself off in a room, tense from the idea that something might crash through the barricaded window, or push aside a wardrobe you used to block a door. Such small little tasks become the biggest deal in this game, and not in a frustrating way; for the story and world keeps you compelled to continue, waiting in anticipation for the next day so that you can get those resources you wanted or explore that location you didn't have time to explore the previous day.
Acid Wizard Studio are doing the best they can to turn this game into an ideal horror experience that any fan of it will enjoy.

Buy it and dive into it, do not look gameplays nor walktrhoughts, it will spoil the thrill of experimenting and exploring. Early Access Review

Hmmm, I'm too lazy to write a long review.

Sooooo...

+Game is hard(and its getting harder with each update,other than item carrier)
+Cool Story and unforgettable characters.
+Fitting soundtracks.
+Nice gameplay and artstyle.
+if you go in a night blindly. Its pretty hard(But I recc. that you should find out the mechanics)
+hmmm...Hard Combattt? I thing that goes in the first one. Oh adding the fact that melee combat is pretty tactical.

-Nights can be pretty easy if you know what to do.(but still its kinda heart pumping bec of the weird noises and events)
-Update schedules are pretty long. Prob. bec there's only 3 people in the dev. team

Allthrough I reccommend this game. Its definitely a worth money spend.
And since its still Early alpha. Game is gonna keep getting bigger with new chapters and locations
